Spoilers
I thought it wasn't bad, Andrew Garfield makes a better Spider Man than he 
does Peter Parker, the chemistry between him and Emma Stone works very 
well. I thought that the story was weak at times, reminding me too much of 
Venom working with Sandman in Spider-Man 3, I actually think that Jamie 
Foxx did a really good job as a goofy, lonely guy, at times it was more 
than a bit much though but he makes up for this when he finally becomes a 
thorough villain. I actually felt more sympathy for Electro and even Harry 
than I did Peter at some points. Harry was a good character but I felt they 
pushed a certain part of the story on him too soon, and the result was 
terrible, especially considering how bad the final product was. But I still 
felt that Dehaans acting was good enough to look past this. Though I do 
believe they've ruined their chances to redeem the character. But the film 
does let itself down with a terrible ending, there was a point it could 
have finished but it took it too far and did a laughably silly ending. ﻿

What I think about the Raimi trilogy is that it added new stories that 
could stand by their own (most of times). Peter was an adult, or a 
teeneager that is almost an adult, however you wanna describe him. That´s 
maybe why his actions and decisions were very complicated, and the writers 
put him in this drama with his new experiences like his powers, his 
studies, work, crime-fighting, etc. And he´s growing up at the same time. 
Which is a part of the character, and that is somehow kept fresh.

The Amazing Spider-man series shows the teenager part of Peter, he doesn´t 
take decisions that well, but the consequences of his actions are going to 
change him in this and other movies, and maybe if they keep doing movies, I 
wish they could make an envolved Peter Parker and Spider-man with better 
stories and focus on maximum two villains united (for example: Green 
Goblin, Venom, Dock Ock, maybe Electro) and one or two sub-plots with other 
villains (something like: I´ve been chasing this "Doc Ock" since he 
appeared in Oscorp, trying to steal something at that moment another 
villain like Shocker appears in a bank with some hostages, menacing to kill 
them if the cops arrive, just to steal some money, almost every villain can 
enter here, depending of the focus of the main villain and the story, 
because the can get the focus away from the main villain) showing character 
development, good writing and good acting in the protagonists, and 
antagonist(s). But, nothing is perfect, it´s just a dream, how I would like 
it to be.

That´s my problem when we are being critics, they work as something to 
improve to make it better, but sometimes we just tell that it´s awful, bad, 
s#it blah, blah. I think we should respect their work, they spent their 
money, time and their bodies to make them after all.

+Ash Cartwright
Dude, Loki isn't sympathetic. He's a spoiled brat who threw a temper 
tantrum. Yeah, he was mad because he was adopted and all, but at least he 
was adopted by royalty. I'm sure he prefers Asgard to Joutenheim. Man kills 
his own biological father and attempts to wipe out his entire race, all to 
win praise from the adopted father who basically stole him. Dude attacks 
New York just cause he feels entitled to a throne. Please, if he had just 
been a good son, he would have been given Asgard anyway since Thor didn't 
want it...

Few people in real life are ever just evil. Most villains in human history 
has thought they were doing something right. Hitler thought he was doing 
the right thing attempting to establish a pure Germany, while we can see 
that as cruel and barbaric, he saw it as righteous. Occasionally you'll get 
a sociopath who does things bad things, but even they aren't doing bad 
things for the sake of doing bad things, its usually to further their own 
interests.

In film, the most relatable villains are ones that the audience can feel 
sympathy for, like the aforementioned Doc Ock in Spiderman 2 or Loki in the 
Marvel Universe. In my experience, there is one pure evil character that is 
unrelatable but still works: The Joker in The Dark Knight.

Of course, this is just my views on what makes a good villain.

+MillzyFilms "you guys are describing literally ever love story ever told" 
and that is why Nicholas Sparks adaptations are all terrible, because they 
follow this convention.

Superhero's love interest is always suppose to be a subplot (that's the 
convention of the genre). However, you can change the conventions of 
existing genre and make it your own.

Christopher Nolan's The Dark Knight and Sam Raimi's Spider-Man 1 and 2 did 
that perfectly. The Dark Knight had the set-pieces of a modern superhero 
movie but the story of a rich crime drama.

Raimi's Spider-Man is more human and emotional than, pretty much, every 
superhero movies ever made (it's the only superhero movie that made me 
cry). Spider-Man 2 gave us more of that and that's why it's better.

These are all very unique films to the superhero genre. Oh, and don't 
forget Superman starring Christopher Reeves with a story that symbolizes 
Christianity.

You can change the convention of romantic comedy/drama as well. Spike 
Jonze's Her did that perfectly. There's a reason why that film was 
nominated for Best Picture and won Best Original Screenplay.

It uses it's sci-fi premise (a man who falls in love with his computer) to 
tell a story about modern relationships and intimacy. It's weird but very 
thoughtful, emotional, original and unique.

Marc Webb tries to do the same thing with TASM (changing the convention) 
and it yields mixed results. The first movie certainly focuses more on the 
love story than most superhero movies, but the whole plot itself is quite 
thin. It's mostly the direction, performances and set-pieces that makes it 
a good movie.

TASM2 also focuses more on storytelling but the story itself is a disaster. 
I appreciate action films with more narrative but if the story is bad, the 
set-pieces would have to make up for it (which it didn't because the 
set-pieces and villain characters were very limited).

TASM2 is full of cheesy, cliche dialogues that makes Peter Parker's 
relationship with Gwen Stacy look more like Twilight. I appreciated the 
chemistry more in the first movie and I still love the characters in the 
second but the typical on-and-off relationship gets more unbearable as the 
movie goes on.

Also, there are multiple story arcs that doesn't go anywhere. There's no 
focus, it just jumps back and forth between plot points.

There's Harry's story, Gwen's story, Max's story and Peter's story. With 
Peter's story, it jumps back and forth between his relationship with Harry, 
Gwen and the origins of his parents. Some ends (one after the other) while 
some are unresolved.

Most superhero movies are cliche but it has entertainment value. There's 
not enough of it in TASM2 like +jm somville said, only around 30 minutes, 
it bored the shit out of me and the story falls flat.

TASM2 has some good points but ultimately, it sucks. This comment is really 
long and I do respect other people's opinions but this whole comment should 
contradict opposing opinions.

Didn't think this flick was bad like most, just very flawed. I mean, the 
storytelling wasn't the best, and Jamie Foxx's Electro was a bit like Jim 
Carrey's Riddler in Batman Forever, and that's not saying anything good. I 
also don't like the film's tiring length and, though Garfield makes a great 
Spider-Man, he doesn't make a good Peter Parker. He's too cocky for my 
taste. However, the relationship between Peter and Gwen is totally 
believe-able and the special effects are outstanding. Combine those effects 
with 3D and you get an experience hard not to remember. Over all, I would 
give Amazing Spidey 2 6.1/10. Though, if you are going to see it, 3D is the 
best option. ﻿

I used to be able to agree with a lot of the angry masses bashing IGN for 
being IGNorant, but lately, I've been noticing a trend. Sure, a 6.9 isn't a 
great score, and sure I haven't even seen the movie, but a huge majority of 
dislikes are from people that are angry it wasn't praised. I think we've 
hit a point in movies and games where you can't just have some good 
performances and good action to hit the higher scores, there has to be 
something different to set it apart from others. Again, a 6.9 isn't a great 
score, but then again, I've seen people rage over 9s because a 9 isn't high 
enough. There are exceptions, of course when we have the right to rage 
(Call of Duty reviews, games and movies that exceeded our wildest 
expectations but only got 8s, etc.), but is this review really all that 
bad? He outlined what he liked about it, and also what he disliked about 
it, giving his reasons for both. Once again, I have not seen the movie, so

Saw it here in the UK and loved it. Yes, the pacing was uneven at times; at 
risk of dragging and you can tell that some scenes were swapped around. But 
the action was off the chain (especially in IMAX 3D), the performances were 
stellar and it earned all it's big moments as a result. The chemistry 
between Garfield and Stone is sizzling hot and the ending with Gwen was 
very well done. I liked the *score* music but whenever it went into pop 
chart music territory it took me out - that's what happens when you enlist 
pop stars rather than real classical musicians, Mr Zimmer.  I think IGN is 
being way harsh. The movie is flawed but succeeds on far more levels than 
it fails.﻿

SPOILERS *********I felt TAS2 had many major flaws. The opening sequence of 
the film didn't feel like it had an overall connection to the whole film 
and what it was going for. The scene was way way to shaky to start of with 
and poorly directed.(almost like transformers) where the camera kept on 
swirling. The script or writing of the movie felt pretty cliche at times. 
The date with Gwen and peter right before the time square battle felt too 
cheesy and felt like it was trying too hard to achieve a sentimental 
response from the audience. The build up of the beginning and middle part 
of the film seemed to be getting somewhere and kept on entertaining us with 
consecutive laughs and cool stunts but when the film ended it felt like 
that whole final showdown and fight achieve the magnitude that it deserved 
for a stable middle part. The supposedly main antagonist Electro i felt was 
poorly written to begin with and didn't seem to give Jaime Foxx much of a 
role to shine upon. His character failed to acquire my care and he felt 
forced at times and his reasoning of trying to kill spiderman seemed bland 
and poor. The things the movie had well though i'd say would be the acting 
between the three, Andrew Garfield, Dane Dehaan and Emma Stone. I felt that 
they were great in the movie and filled the roles with much belief and 
satisfaction. Andrew playing spiderman showed great sides of comic relief 
and sorrow, whereas Emma Stone and Dane were also great but didn't seem to 
have as much 'abundance' of a script to really explore their talents in 
acting. Their scripts were much less expanded as the main protagonists but 
they were still great with what they had.(Dane especially :3). Overall i 
felt the movie suffered from displaying the direction the film was taking 
and the lack of a well written script and dialouge. The actors (most of 
them) were great and had decent special effects and fight scenes. But 
really didn't quite capture the magnitude the directors seemed to be 
focusing. 7/10 okay for me too. Just my opinion im only 14 :3 ﻿

The light-hearted tone is the biggest and best thing in this movie's 
favour. It was a conscious and correct decision to bring us back to a fun 
bright world because (despite going back to the tone of the Raimi flicks 
which SONY so desperately seemed to want to get away from) Spidey just 
belongs in this kinda movieverse. So superficially the movie is at least 
enjoyable to watch and it'll definitely attract the kids more than its poor 
predecessor did. But then you watch the film and you feel like I'm back in 
2007 - it's "Spider-Man 3" all over again in that the film tries to cram SO 
many plot points into its run time that nothing ever seems to have time to 
play out properly and then add to that all the set-ups for sequels it 
throws in and the whole thing just feels really jumbled and you get a sense 
that it's at the sacrifice of a good story. It's certainly better than its 
predecessor but the tone only gets it so far. Why did they feel the need to 
cram so much shit in here when they KNOW they have a good three sequels 
coming up which gives them the movie-time all these stories would need to 
play out properly.

I also found the shoehorning of the Green Goblin slightly insulting. They 
shove him in at the last minute for one final act and it's literally just 
so that they can recreate a particular scene from the comics to distract 
it's core fan base from all of its biggest problems. Sorry SONY, but I'm 
not buying it. Nice try.  ﻿

Totally agree with the review and the end score. Seen it yesterday and 
while it is not a bad movie, it certainly was a disappointment.
This was the movie of Gwen and Peter alone. And while that would not be a 
bad thing per sé, this would have fit better in a television series as 
ongoing character development. This took lots of moments away to develop 
the rest of the story and characters.
Rhino's a throw-in gag-villain who screams his own name (seriously?), 
Electro has quite a good story build-up but a finish that's wasted in 
(arguably bad) CGI over story and Harry's Story is just horribly written as 
something that had to tie everything together (but doesn't make any sense 
if you think about it logically). And Harry's finish got cut short for 
another finale (which I won't spoil).
And the whole thing about how Peter handled his father's revelations... 
wow, that was certainly worth a plane crash [/sarcasm].
The movie had its good moments (Times Square scene, many humorous scenes, 
good overall acting, good music, etc), but the end result left me quite 
disappointed.﻿

this is a review from comicbookmovie.com
Comic book movies in recent years have tended to be greeted with great 
regularity with the description 'darker' or variations thereof. This 
culminated with the excellent but 'darker' The Dark Knight , which bordered 
on pitch-black and outright depressing (I still love the film nonetheless). 
However, the latest incarnation of the Spiderman movie series, the Amazing 
Spiderman 2 has followed in the footsteps of The Avengers by lightening up 
and getting back to the roots of the comic, with puns and one-liners galore 
giving the film a much more entertaining vibe than the convoluted and 
take-themselves-too-seriously original trilogy. However, the comedy 
generally doesn't overshadow the story too much, and themes of loss, love, 
responsibility and isolation are more deftly dealt with, making this new 
Marvel superhero film a more rounded experience, which again paves the way 
for yet another franchise. 
 
The opening sequence at the very least ties up some loose ends on what 
happened with Peter's parents (something that was just dropped in the first 
film).There's a quick montage of Richard Parker experimenting with some 
Spiders at Oscorp before going against Oscorp when he finds out they want 
to use his research for unmoral things. The flash back from the first movie 
comes next before we see Richard and Mary on a jet. They're attacked by an 
assasin who has killed the co-pilot. The sequence is very brutal and 
emotional because Peter's parents sacrifice their own lives trying to 
expose Oscorp and its corruption. The plane goes down and we cut to black 
and there's a smooth transition where we see Spiderman's symbol appear from 
the darkness . With the upbeat score/soundtrack playing in the back ground, 
 woohoos and yells are heard coming from our friendly neighbourhood 
Spider-man as he swings though the New York City skyscrappers in his new 
classic costume. Spidey's first mission is to deal with an armoured car 
heist. This is where we're introduced to Aleksei. The chase is filled with 
some breath-taking swinging scenes, some hilarious one-liners from Spidey 
and an over-the top performance by Paul Giamatti. Spidey is more energetic 
and confident than ever. The Amazing Spiderman 2 seems to belong to the 
Spiderman character. That means things are more elastic and energetic, with 
a new found emphasis on the kinetic motion of Spider-Man, swinging through 
NYC. 


 
Undoubtedly the best thing about this film is the performances from the two 
leads in the film, Andrew Garfield (Peter Parker / Spider-Man) and Emma 
Stone (Gwen Stacey). At the core of this movie is the irresistible love 
story between Peter and Gwen, delicately played by Andrew Garfield and Emma 
Stone. Their chemistry that makes the love feel genuine. The acting is 
uniformly great, from Garfield and Stone especially. It's fair to say that 
Garfield's performance is not close to surpassing his incredible role as 
Eduardo in 'The Social Network', but that is certainly not a criticism. His 
performance is well-rounded, believable, and his ability to play adolescent 
so perfectly is certainly one of the best in the business right now. He 
gave his best performance in this movie. Similarly, Emma Stone is again 
very believable and the pair has a certain dynamic, an on screen 
connection, which is incredibly satisfying for the audience to watch as the 
narrative progresses. She's given a lot more depth and character 
development, something I found solely lacking in the first film. Their 
chemistry is undoubtely even better and felt more natural and less twilight 
like in the first film.
 
The supporting performances from Dane Dehaan, Jaimie Foxx , and Sally Field 
are excellent, although I can't help but wish they'd have given Paul 
Giamatti and his character Aleksei Sytsevich a bit more screentime. His 
performance as the character was over the top and cheesy but it provided 
some laughs especially during the chase scene and when he's in the Rhino 
suit. I was somewhat dissapointed with Jaimie Foxx's Electro. His character 
Max is in the same vein, Riddler , Killian and Syndrome. There wasn't that 
much they could have done with the character but only make him a powerful 
threat and a visually stunning villain. He did good with what he worked 
with.  The real villain here is Oscorp, Electro is more of a pawn 
manipulated by Harry. Dane Dehaan is the highlight of the film. He is akin 
to how Two-Face appeared in Dark Knight. He certainly did a better job than 
Franco and he's Goblin was scary but fell short of Dafoe's Goblin. The 
character is given depth and you really have to pay attention to understand 
his motives. Sally Field was good given with what she had to work with. I 
just can't help feel that she's just there. Hopefully she's given a lot 
more to do in the sequel. Chris Cooper wasn't in the film that much and 
Denis Leary and Martin Sheen make cameo appearences.


 
The film is visually stunning. The ending set pieces are satisfactory 
visually, and the audience get just the right amount of POV web-swinging 
shots to leave them satisfied and not left with motion sickness. This is 
the most fun we've had web-slinging with our wall crawler. An 
over-the-shoulder shot zooms in on the down swings and backs out with the 
up swings. Spidey's impressive acrobatics are on full display in slow more/ 
sped-up shots thanks to the Matrix (the new spidey sense borderlines on 
some matrix -esque slo mo shots highlighted in the Times Square battle.The 
action is dare I say it, spectacular! With the highlights being the Times 
Square battle and the Power Plant fight. Those were the most visually 
appealing sequences in the film, especially in IMAX 3D. The CGI is just 
perfect given the how far technology has advanced. There are a couple of 
times were you notice the CGI but it's barely noticeable. The final fight 
scene is probably the most intense fight scene I've seen this year. Here is 
truly where Dehaan's shines as the green goblin. He's crazy and menacing 
and him and Spidey duke it out in one of the most brutal fight scenes. I 
was on the edge of my seat and very anxious. The payoff is very 
satisfactory. You won't see it coming.
 
While it is unlikely this film will win any original screenplay awards, 
particularly given the mere decade that has passed since the original 
Spiderman film debuted, The Amazing Spiderman 2 is an enjoyable entry into 
Marvel's comic book film adaptation canon, dealing deftly with the familiar 
themes without beating the audience over the head. Orzi, Kurztman and 
Pinkett should be praised for their script in this film. It's a sharply 
written script with witty humour and very intense dramatic moments (in 
particular the final fight). Of course there's a few eye roll moments but 
it's a Spiderman movie, we should expect those but they're nothing severe. 
The script is very well constructed and pretty straight-forward.


 
Despite this being a clear superhero comic book movie film, the superhero 
antics seem to take a back seat (even though there's a lot of action) and 
we are allowed to delve deeper into the characters. Peter Parker is clearly 
over-confident and full of himself at the start of the film only to have 
his whole world turned upside down at the end. He's a guy who has grown up 
having a troubled life which isn't about to get any easier and the 
relationships he forms with his Uncle Aunt and long time friend Harry are 
all really well written, his relationship with Gwen Stacy (a vital part of 
Spider-Man history in the comic books) is dealt with wonderfully and with a 
huge deal of respect. You get a real sense that all of these characters are 
believable in their motivations, their friendships, their triumphs and 
short comings. The characters and the sequences in this film operate on a 
level of emotional depth that is several notches deeper than that in the 
first three Spidey-flicks. I won't spoil the ending, but it's very well 
done, It leaves you and anticipating the 3rd film even more. Director Marc 
Webb, who's only other director's credit before the first film was 500 Days 
of Summer, did a great job creating a gritty, modern-day Spider-Man. All 
the actors are superb, the action is great, the special effects are amazing 
(especially the first-person web swinging scenes), and the story is very 
well done. It's now clear this new universe is headed in a different 
direction.
 
For someone who wasn't fond of the first film, I must say this film did 
many things for me as a viewer. I literally sat back and watched as a very 
good love story for a adolescent character in a superhero film was shown 
before me.The characters are developed far more smoothly and emotionally, 
taking the humor the original trilogy had out of their growth and replacing 
it with serious backgrounds and story lines. This film really overwhelmed 
me, and surprised me in every way. With all the characters given respect, 
it goes without saying that the film also handles the spectacle with equal 
measure. Here, you'll believe a man really can do those death-defying 
swings. The action is brutal and intense, as are the consequences Peter 
suffers. There's a true sense of danger. But it's not all gloom, he's the 
wise-cracking web-slinger so many people had originally wanted. The humour 
is not of the juvenile kind that plagued the other films. It's well-placed 
here, smart and actually funny. Appropriate director Marc Webb ensures 
there's not a dull moment in the film, even during its 'slower' parts. It 
keeps you transfixed. This movie does contain a sense of sadness, romance, 
uplifting relief, and action-packed adrenaline. There are some scenes that 
remain calm at first but then jump right out at you. Every major gripe I 
had with the first film has been addressed here. This is by far the best 
comic book movie this year so far.  I recommend you all go see it in IMAX 3D

Okay people. Its not just IGN.. All the critics are giving this movie below 
average reviews and I just don't understand why.

I think its something to do with Andrew Garfield saying "screw the critics" 
before the movie came out; maybe they all got offended by that and wanted 
to give this movie a bad review.. Anyways:

 In my opinion it was the best Spider Man movie to date, if anything it's 
the best Marvel movie to date; and I'm going to tell you why with spoilers, 
so don't read this until you've seen the movie.

The movie opens up strongly finally revealing the mystery of Peter's 
parents' death that we were wondering about since the last movie. Then 
afterwards it comes in full force with the action and cheesy one liners 
that we all know Spider Man to be so well for. Critics call it "cheesy" in 
a bad way, but that is just how Spider Man's character is; Andrew Garfield 
plays it perfectly. 

*SPOILER* 

Emma Stone and Andrew Garfield both play their parts well due to their 
chemistry on screen. They are dating in real life so that makes a big 
difference and Marc Webb's directing between the two characters is 
emotional and real; especially when Gwen is killed by the Goblin. This was 
already being set up by Peter being emotionally torn by Gwen's father being 
killed, so it was even more emotional when she was killed. 

Electro is thrown in almost right away with 40 minutes of character 
development in between, and Green Goblin/Harry Osborn has very good reason 
to be a villain in this movie because Spider Man and Peter is torn between 
giving Harry his blood to cure the disease passed down by his father who 
died, and he is not able to because, hes, well, Spider Man.. They are both 
great villains to be put in because they both have their own sense of 
revenge. Max Dillon's character was captured/Tortured mainly because of 
Spider Man, so it only makes sense. This movie isn't necessarily over 
crowded with villains at all. I will admit that the Goblin is brought in at 
a later point, but it wasn't necessarily a bad thing. You'd have to see the 
movie to know what I'm talking about.

The special effects in the movie are spectacular, and Electro's character 
helps out with this a lot.

The movie is ended on a high note with Spider Man fighting against Rhino, 
but it's mainly because it is setting up for either Amazing Spider Man 3 or 
the Sinister Six movie. 

I was going into this movie expecting a decent super hero movie, I was 
skeptic because of the critics but man are they wrong. Everyone needs to go 
see this movie. It is by far the best super hero movie besides maybe the 
Nolan Batman trilogy. 

10/10﻿

anything the film needed to pull off it's ending (which anyone could see

it by that time. They made a good Spiderman PRODUCT, but not a good movie.

Just finished watching the movie, and as a sequel to the Amazing Spider-Man 
it was a superior film. Though the plot is overwhelming with twists and 
turns, it still has enough inertia to make it through. Characters are 
likable, motivations clear and understandable, interactions between them 
aren't forced. There are some kick ass scenes in this film that have 
emotionally heavy moments, some were bit unexpected. However there are some 
scenes that felt like they were shoved in just to kill time and they were 
put in such action packed scenes, that it actually hurt the watching 
experience. 
In the end, I liked this film, it was a good time. If I would compare this 
movie with recent ones, it would be like Thor 2. It was a tasty dessert, 
that I ate with pleasure. I give this film 7/10.﻿

supporting/minor characters. And this movie only has three big plot points: 
Peter's relationship with Gwen, The Oscorp conspiracy/Pete's parents, and 
Harry Osborn's own desperation for a cure. And the stuff with Peter's 
parents explains why Harry shouldn't use Spider-Man's blood as a cure, so 
it really all ties together in the end. The movie wasn't perfect, 
obviously. Like when Max is in that prison cell and suddenly calls himself 
Electro. I think that if Spidey at least nicknamed him Electro at one point 
during the Times Square fight, then it would have seemed a bit less out of 
place. And Max's daydream of snapping at Smythe wasn't all that needed. 
There were little moments like that throughout the film, but it didn't 
distract from the experience overall. I think the movie was still very well 
done, especially with the acting. Marc Webb picked great people for these 
characters, and I'm really excited about what they have in store for us in 
the future.﻿

I feel the main element that lets this film down is the CGI. The first 
'Amazing Spider-Man' uses digital effects in such a way that as a viewer, 
the transitions from real to unreal are seamless.

The CG Electro would have been passable in a big budget blockbuster 10 
years ago, but technology has come so far now, Jamie Foxx's character 
stands out like a sore thumb; which for me, pushes me straight out of the 
drama.

There were a couple of dodgy moments with the CG Spidey, but on the whole 
the character looked ok.

'The Avengers' and 'Captain America 2' have raised the bar for super hero 
films. I don't expect Sony to catch up, but I hope they're at least come 
somewhere close for the next installment of Spider-man!﻿

Got to agree with this review, the movie was so underwhelming. In terms of 
CGI and action and such it did a pretty good job, nothing phenomenal but 
the movie was really confident in itself which was good.
But story wise it was so mediocre, so many of the plot points felt useless 
and disjointed. None of the scenes felt particularly relevant, they all 
felt like they were part of a bigger machine, one that you never even see. 
The storyline is so overstuffed with characters that none of them are 
properly developed, especially electro. The writing was a disappointment as 
well, there are so many cliché's and poorly developed moments in the story, 
the way everything falls into place feels a little too convenient.
I kind of respect what this movie was trying to do, even though the whole 
thing felt like one giant advertisement, but that doesn't change the fact 
it had some of the worst storytelling I've seen in a comic book movie.
I'd say 7/10, and that's being generous.﻿

The few good things about this movie :

- Electro, for what little we had of him.

origin story of two vilains (electro's was actually really good) while 
really putting a LOT of attention on the relationship between Petter and 
Gwen (Which as far as love stories goes... is... meh).

The end result is a VERY long movie, that as too much dialog for a 
superhero movie (and the quality if the said dialog is not enough to carry 
the movie) and a few action scenes that are very far in between.

When will they ever learn that putting to much origin/side stories into one 
movie is NEVER a good idea! You need to look no further then Spider man 3!

The avengers worked because EACH character had their own origin story in 
their own movies. So they wasted no time getting into the meat of things 
when they all teamed up togheter. You can't do all that stuff in ONE movie!

The amazing spider had a lot of potential but ended up average due to the 
terrible... TERRIBLE pacing.

So far this reboot (First movie was ok) doesn't surpass Raimi's original 
spiderman I and II.

You should never be bored when watching a spiderman movie.
